summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of a motion to dismiss the superseding indictment against her. The motion argues that the indictment was obtained in violation of the Sixth Amendment because the grand jury was drawn from the White Plains Division during the COVID-19 pandemic, which allegedly systematically underrepresented Black and Hispanic residents compared to the Manhattan Division where the alleged crimes occurred.

locations: Manhattan Division (New York, Bronx, Westchester, Putnam, Rockland counties)
White Plains Division (Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Orange, Sullivan, Dutchess counties)
keyFacts: The defense argues Ghislaine Maxwell's indictment was obtained using a grand jury drawn from the White Plains Division, which systematically underrepresented Black and Hispanic residents compared to the Manhattan Division where the alleged crimes occurred.

An expert analysis cited found the White Plains qualified jury wheel was 8.76% Black and 10.48% Hispanic, compared to the Manhattan Division's eligible juror population of 20.92% Black and 28.06% Hispanic.

The defense claims the government chose the White Plains grand jury to meet a "publicity-driven" deadline of July 2, 2020, the anniversary of Jeffrey Epstein's indictment, despite a Manhattan grand jury being available on June 25, 2020.
The motion contends this selection process violated Maxwell's Sixth Amendment right to a grand jury drawn from a fair cross-section of the community, warranting dismissal of the indictment.
The alleged criminal conduct, specifically involving Epstein's Upper East Side residence, is tied solely to the Manhattan Division, with no alleged unlawful acts in the White Plains Division.
